explanation: The report is not correct. MISRA R2.1 targets code that exists in the compiled program but can never be executed (dead/unreachable code in the translation unit). The WSASocketW branch is excluded by the preprocessor when MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS and SOCK_CLOEXEC (or SOCK_NOSIGPIPE) are defined, so that fragment does not become part of the compiled translation unit in that build configuration. Conditional-compilation alternatives that are not selected are not "unreachable" at runtime because they are simply not compiled into the project binary; they can become compiled and reachable under a different configuration. Therefore there is no violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 in the given configuration.
